intro: Phacelia cookei, commonly known as Cook's phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its showy blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils in open habitats such as meadows and slopes. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and it blooms from late spring to early summer. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
